awd_titl_txt: Topographic Amplification of Seismic Motion: Observations and Simulations in 3D
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides funding for the development of computational tools that will allow large-scale numerical simulations to be conducted to study the response of 2D and 3D convex and concave topographic features. Using these tools, a systematic parametric investigation will be performed to quantify the role of topogra­phic geometry, stratigraphy, soil nonlinearity and ground motion characteristics in site res­ponse. Numerical predictions will be validated via comparison with published field data from 3D arrays, speci­fically deployed to evaluate topographic ampli­fication effects. Numerical results and field observations will be finally compiled to develop simplified procedures for accounting of topography effects in engineering design practice.

If successful, the results from this work will impact engineering design practices nationwide. While seismic hazard assessment and microzonation studies rely increasingly on wave motion simulations, most developments to date do not account for topographical features, making the sweeping assumption of a flat earth surface model. Observations from large earthquakes, however, have shown that the pre­sence of a strong topographic relief can significantly aggravate the catastrophic conse­quences of strong seismic motion. These effects of topography on site response may not be predicted by the widely employed flat surface models, and this work will lead to a next generation of wave motion simu­lation tools that take into account local topography. In addition, this work will contribute to the deve­lopment of design topographic amplification factors for generic features, to be implemented in excess of existing site amplification factors, and account for the topographic aggra­vation of ground motion.

The founding of components of the built environment in seismic-prone areas requires that the ground-surface motion produced by strong earthquakes be taken into account, in order to assist in the design of earthquake-resistant structures. A reasonable approach in assessing the potential earthquake impact requires the computational modeling and simulation of the associated seismic motion. Most simulations to date are conducted by making overly-simplifying assumptions that, among others, either ignore the complexity the heterogeneity of the soil introduces, or ignore the three-dimensional nature of the problem, or both.  Another pervasive simplifying assumption is that earth’s crust is flat, which ignores the role the topography (mountains, hills, valleys, etc) plays on the seismic motion.

To address the above shortcomings, at the University of Texas at Austin, we concentrated on two primary tasks: (i) firstly, the development of the software tool chain that would allow the numerical simulation of seismic motion within arbitrarily heterogeneous three-dimensional regions, accounting for the simultaneous presence of arbitrary-geometry topographic features, whether these are terrain depressions, terrain protrusions, or of a general complex nature. (ii) secondly, following the development of the software, we concentrated on the use of the tool chain to study the effect topography has on the amplification of seismic motion.  At Georgia Tech we developed analytical solutions of simplified problems (such as a wedge or a pyramid) and used existing numerical tools to: (iii) understand the role that various parameters play in the physics of seismic shaking modification by topographic features. Examples include the height, width, slope, incidence of seismic motion, amplitude, frequency of shaking and stratigraphy of the underlying soil. We then studied the effects of the above parameters for realistic isolated topographic features, with complex geometry, stratigraphy and ground shaking characteristics.

The first task has been completed and has resulted in a state-of-the-art seismic motion simulator, one of the primary technical outcomes of the award. Pictorially, the capability is captured in the motion simulation depicted in Figure 1, where an incoming plane wave impinges on three topographic features (idealized as pyramids); various snapshots in time are shown. The novel elements of our development have already been reported in the scientific literature. 

Using this software, the analytical models we developed and existing numerical simulations tools, we conducted a series of parametric studies in two and three dimensions, for various topographic features, idealized by simple ground-surface protruding or intruding geometries, and various underlying soil stratigraphy configurations. Overall, the seismic motion can be greatly amplified, compared to flat-surface assumptions, by several times and especially within a topographic protrusion, depending on the seismic input’s and topographic feature’s characteristics (frequency content, direction of travel, feature geometry, etc) (example in Figure 2). This implies the need for the careful design of structures founded on hill and mountain sides. Interestingly, we also report the presence of deamplification zones away from the topographic feature, which may lead to the relaxation of seismic design requirements.
